Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: The launch date was moved up and architects from multiple teams are blocked until they provide decisions
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stared at my laptop, Slack pinging with urgent messages. The architects from three teams were waiting for my input on the new feature design, and the launch date had just been moved up. My manager’s message was clear: “We need your decisions today, or the whole project stalls.” I glanced at the clock—just enough time to vote before my next meeting. At the polling station, the line was long but moving. Suddenly, an official called out, “Voters A–M, please move to the new line!” My last name started with B. The new line looked chaotic, but the official’s voice was insistent. I hesitated, torn. As a developer, I was expected to collaborate and not be the bottleneck. As a voter, I was supposed to follow instructions, even if it meant waiting longer. My phone buzzed again—another urgent message. I felt the pressure mounting, caught between the demands of my team and my civic duty, unsure which expectation to honor first.
